h4.a: CMCSS Schools Closed for the Rest of the 2019-2020 School Year

div.style: height: 280px; width: 100%; background-image: url(https://cmcss.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/3.png); background-size: cover; background-position: center; margin-top: -16px;

br.span: This page provides guidance on Continued Learning Resources available during the closure due to COVID-19. Children thrive within structured environments, and it will be important to provide opportunities during the day for your children to be creative, read and discuss what they are reading, and participate in physical activity. It is a good idea to create a daily structure in... READ MORE

div.style: height: 280px; width: 100%; background-image: url(https://cmcss.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/1.png); background-size: cover; background-position: center; margin-top: -16px;

br.span: Over the past few weeks, a Communicable Disease Team (CDT) comprised of leaders from CMCSS and the Montgomery County Health Department have been meeting regularly to review the latest guidance from the CDC, monitor the health and attendance of CMCSS students and employees, and make recommendations to mitigate the spread of COVID-19 and other communicable diseases. READ MORE

div.style: height: 280px; width: 100%; background-image: url(https://cmcss.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/2.png); background-size: cover; background-position: center; margin-top: -16px;

br.span: Effective Monday, March 23 until further notice, meals for children will be served Monday, Wednesday and Friday from 10 a.m. to noon at the following locations: Barkers Mill Elementary, Barksdale Elementary, Burt Elementary, Byrns Darden Elementary, Cumberland Heights Elementary, Glenellen Elementary, Kenwood Elementary, Minglewood Elementary, Moore Elementary, Norman Smith Elementary, Ringgold Elementary, and Woodlawn Elementary and Kenwood High, Montgomery Central... READ MORE

img.title: Clarksville-Montgomery County School System
img.alt: Clarksville-Montgomery County School System

p.span:
The following Class of 2020 Graduation update was emailed this evening to seniors and their parents/guardians:
Good evening, Class of 2020 and parents/guardians,
Thank you to everyone who responded to the survey that the district sent on April 16. CMCSS’ goal was to develop a plan for graduation ceremonies in collaboration with you, taking into consideration your feedback and ideas while balancing that with guidance regarding COVID-19 safety from state and federal agencies. After reviewing feedback from over 1,700 responses to the survey, the following plan has been developed.
Graduation Ceremonies:
The district will move forward with planning smaller, in-person graduation ceremonies for each high school over the summer months. With continued guidelines limiting the size of gatherings and factoring in the capacities of our football stadiums, we will have to limit guests and make other modifications for the safety and health of graduates, guests, and employees. At this time with social-distancing guidelines, please anticipate a limit of at most two guests per graduate, which is subject to change based on guidelines at the time. Additionally, with the uncertainty of future stay-at-home orders, we are planning June dates as well as backup dates in July. In the event of inclement weather, the graduation ceremonies will be moved inside and guests would be further limited. We are committed to recording these ceremonies so other family members may watch at a later date.
Please see the graphic on this post for the dates of these ceremonies. Times, locations, and further directions will be communicated by June 1. The goal is to hold these ceremonies in the morning.
Online Celebrations:
Although the district will be moving forward with planning in-person graduation ceremonies over the summer months, we recognize that not all students may be able to attend. We also are faced with an unprecedented situation that could affect our plans for summer graduations. With this in mind, CMCSS will also move forward with online graduation celebrations in May. School and district personnel will be working over the coming weeks to create these celebration videos that will individually recognize each graduating senior. These will be streamed online during the regularly scheduled graduation dates and times in May.
The district will provide more information on how to view these celebrations in the coming weeks. There is no action required on your part unless your school reaches out to you with a request.
Yard Signs:
Thanks to the CMC Education Foundation with sponsorships from CDE Lightband, Agero, F&M Bank, Google, James Corlew Chevrolet, Q Realty, Reliant Bank, and Wyatt Johnson Automotive Group and a partnership with Gerald Printing, the district will be able to provide Class of 2020 yard signs for each graduate! Instructions regarding the distribution of these signs will be communicated in the coming weeks.

img.alt:
The following Class of 2020 Graduation update was emailed this evening to seniors and their parents/guardians:
Good evening, Class of 2020 and parents/guardians,
Thank you to everyone who responded to the survey that the district sent on April 16. CMCSS’ goal was to develop a plan for graduation ceremonies in collaboration with you, taking into consideration your feedback and ideas while balancing that with guidance regarding COVID-19 safety from state and federal agencies. After reviewing feedback from over 1,700 responses to the survey, the following plan has been developed.
Graduation Ceremonies: The district will move forward with planning smaller, in-person graduation ceremonies for each high school over the summer months. With continued guidelines limiting the size of gatherings and factoring in the capacities of our football stadiums, we will have to limit guests and make other modifications for the safety and health of graduates, guests, and employees. At this time with social-distancing guidelines, please anticipate a limit of at most two guests per graduate, which is subject to change based on guidelines at the time. Additionally, with the uncertainty of future stay-at-home orders, we are planning June dates as well as backup dates in July. In the event of inclement weather, the graduation ceremonies will be moved inside and guests would be further limited. We are committed to recording these ceremonies so other family members may watch at a later date.
Please see the graphic on this post for the dates of these ceremonies. Times, locations, and further directions will be communicated by June 1. The goal is to hold these ceremonies in the morning.
Online Celebrations: Although the district will be moving forward with planning in-person graduation ceremonies over the summer months, we recognize that not all students may be able to attend. We also are faced with an unprecedented situation that could affect our plans for summer graduations. With this in mind, CMCSS will also move forward with online graduation celebrations in May. School and district personnel will be working over the coming weeks to create these celebration videos that will individually recognize each graduating senior. These will be streamed online during the regularly scheduled graduation dates and times in May.
The district will provide more information on how to view these celebrations in the coming weeks. There is no action required on your part unless your school reaches out to you with a request.
Yard Signs: Thanks to the CMC Education Foundation with sponsorships from CDE Lightband, Agero, F&M Bank, Google, James Corlew Chevrolet, Q Realty, Reliant Bank, and Wyatt Johnson Automotive Group and a partnership with Gerald Printing, the district will be able to provide Class of 2020 yard signs for each graduate! Instructions regarding the distribution of these signs will be communicated in the coming weeks.

p.span: TN PromiseSTUDENTS: Due to the current state of emergency related to #COVID19, the Tennessee Promise April 1 community service requirement has been waived. Please visit and bookmark this site for regular updates: www.tn.gov/thec/covid-19-campus-information.html

div.p: The official Instagram account of the Clarksville-Montgomery County School System.

a.span: Dear parents, we appreciate you partnering with us

img.alt: Dear parents, we appreciate you partnering with us to help students stay engaged in their education with the CMCSS Continued Learning Library! If you’d like to share pictures of your children learning at home, please tag them @cmcssinfo #cmcsscontinuedlearning We miss having your children in class, and look forward to seeing all that they are learning from home!!!

a.span: While it takes over 5,000 people with various tale

img.alt: While it takes over 5,000 people with various talents and expertise to keep the district operating at high level, we want to give a huge thanks to our nurses, custodians, and Child Nutrition staff who have gone above and beyond to keep our students fed and the entire CMCSS family as safe and healthy as possible during this pandemic. #cmcss #differencemakers
#cmcss #elementaryschool #EMES #JOY

a.span: It is Read Across America Week! CHS Spanish 3 & 4

img.alt: It is Read Across America Week! CHS Spanish 3 & 4 students visited Barksdale today to read to their 1st grade Spanish Immersion students, with whom they have been pen pals this year. We want to see your CMCSS Read Across America Week photos! Tag them with @cmcssinfo so we can share them throughout the day. #cmcss #readacrossamerica #cmcssreadacrossamerica #readacrossamericaweek #spanishimmersion #BES #CHS #drseussweek

a.span: March is Youth Art Month. CMCSS students celebrate

img.alt: March is Youth Art Month. CMCSS students celebrate by showcasing their masterpieces at the Montgomery County Library. #cmcss #youthartmonth #SES
Spread joy today. #cmcss #elementaryschool #choosejoy #HES
#cmcss #elementaryschool #SBES #prek

a.span: Four years ago, Kimberly Bellamy began bringing go

img.alt: Four years ago, Kimberly Bellamy began bringing golden retrievers registered with Pet Partners animal therapy program to classrooms in CMCSS. With the three dogs combined, Mrs. Bellamy has visited CMCSS schools 140 times, which amounts to over 200 hours. They have visited 14 elementary schools, 2 middle schools, 2 high schools; in addition to the Synergy Program and the Learning Center. Visits have been related to "animals in the community" lessons, behavior incentives, and socialization for CDC students as well. But the majority of visits are to strengthen reading confidence using the student-animal bond. There is no judgment from a dog. Charlie, Skiff and Penny are their names. The Bellamy dogs are registered with the Pet Partners animal therapy program, and each have to pass the evaluation every two years. Significant training goes in to preparing for the test, but more importantly, the animal has to have the temperament to be a therapy dog. They have to enjoy meeting new people and have excellent manners in public. Charlie and Skiff have almost equal number of visits. Penny has just 18 visits with CMCSS. Richview Middle School teacher Michelle Main and West Creek Elementary School teacher Karma Sherk have consistently invited Mrs. Bellamy to their classrooms on a monthly basis, year after year. They have seen what an effect it has on their students and have been so committed to participating. #cmcss #wces #Charlie #therapydogs

a.span: Students from the Academy of Teaching and Learning

img.alt: Students from the Academy of Teaching and Learning at WCHS work with students at WCES on a weekly basis. #cmcss #elementaryschool #highschool #academy #WCHS #WCES
